prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 4 line observations of far-infrared-detected galaxies
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(4-3) and CI(1-0) observations of 19 galaxies selected in the far-infrared and submillimetre.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request spectroscopic observations of the CO(4-3), redshifted to band 4. (We note that the CI(1-0) is also present in this band but the large variation in the L_CO(4-3)/L_CI(1-0) ratio (Alaghband-Zadeh et al. 2013, MNRAS, 435, 1493) means that we base these calculations on the CO(4-3) line.) Using our LABOCA and Herschel observations we estimate IR-luminosities between 2.5-7x10^12 L_solar. This translates into L′_CO(1−0) luminosities of at least 2–3×10^10 K km s^-1 pc^2 (Ivison et al. 2011, MNRAS, 412, 1913). Taking into account a median brightness temperature ratio of r_43 = 0.41 (Bothwell et al. 2013, MNRAS, 429, 3047), we aim to achieve an integrated line intensity of at least I_CO(4-3) = 0.6 Jy km/s for the CO(4-3) transition. The typical FWHM value of submillimetre galaxies is 500 km s^−1 (Bothwell et al. 2013). Adopting this value, we estimate a minimum flux density of >= 1.2 mJy for CO(4-3). Therefore an rms sensitivity of 0.4 mJy will ensure we detect the line at the >=3 sigma level. We expect our targets to be point sources to the highest ALMA resolution. We therefore take an angular resolution of 3.0 arcsec for the time calculation.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Protoclusters, ancestors of local galaxy clusters, provide a unique opportunity to trace the emergence of large-scale structure, and to study galaxy evolution in dense environments. Our recent large Herschel survey of 19 protocluster fields confirmed 1138-262, 'the Spiderweb galaxy', as the most massive z>2 protocluster. We propose to target the CO(4-3) and CI(1-0) lines of all the candidate protocluster starburst galaxies from our Herschel data in this field. The observations will determine membership, and result in the first complete sample of starburst galaxies with log L > 12.4 L_solar in a protocluster.
These data will for the first time (1) measure the properties (star-formation rates, molecular gas mass, ISM) of this population, and trace how they differ from field galaxies; (2) accurately determine the velocity dispersion of the protocluster and its sub-structures; and (3) constrain the overall characteristics (size, mass, morphology) of this protocluster and place them in a cosmological context via comparison with numerical simulations. ALMA is the only facility with the necessary combination of spatial and spectral resolution and high sensitivity to achieve these goals.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00788.S Revealing the nature of massive, dusty starbursts around the Spiderweb galaxy
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
